payload.name: reflective-equilibrium
payload.core: Iteratively adjust both abstract principles and concrete case judgments until they cohere. Neither theory nor intuition has automatic priority; both evolve together through mutual revision. Equilibrium is dynamic: new cases can destabilize it, requiring fresh iteration.
out: principle_set: numbered list of general rules with version history showing revisions
case_inventory: table mapping cases to (judgment, governing_principle, confidence)
tension_log: record of conflicts found and how each was resolved (principle_revised | judgment_revised | exception_carved | tension_accepted)
revision_trace: ordered list of (old_state, trigger_case, new_state, justification)
equilibrium_certificate: final coherence claim with coverage metrics (cases_tested, principles_stable, residual_tensions)
proc: 1. SEED: write down 3-7 candidate principles; list 10+ concrete cases with intuitive judgments before seeing principles
2. MAP: for each case, identify which principle(s) apply; mark conflicts where principle implies X but intuition says not-X
3. WEIGH: for each conflict, score (a) principle strength (generality, prior success) vs (b) intuition strength (clarity, stability under reflection)
4. REVISE: if intuition dominates, narrow/qualify the principle; if principle dominates, update the judgment and note why intuition was unreliable
5. PROPAGATE: after any revision, re-test all prior cases against updated principle set; log new conflicts
6. ITERATE: repeat steps 2-5 until a full pass produces zero new conflicts or only tensions you explicitly accept
7. STRESS-TEST: generate 3 adversarial cases designed to break equilibrium; if any succeeds, return to step 3
8. CERTIFY: produce equilibrium_certificate listing coverage, residual tensions, and conditions that would reopen review
check: principle_set has version >= 2 (at least one revision occurred)
case_inventory covers >= 10 cases including >= 3 marked 'hard' at outset
tension_log shows >= 1 principle revision AND >= 1 judgment revision (bidirectional adjustment)
no case removed from inventory without explicit 'excluded because...' entry
equilibrium_certificate states residual tensions (0 is suspicious; usually 1-3 accepted)
revision_trace is non-empty and each entry has a justification
quick_checklist: Did I revise at least one principle? (if no, may have privileged theory)
Did I revise at least one judgment? (if no, may have privileged intuition)
Did I test adversarial cases I didn't author? (if no, confirmation bias risk)
Can I state residual tensions explicitly? (if vague, equilibrium is shallow)
Would a skeptic find my revision_trace persuasive? (if not, justifications are weak)

diff.deductive: deduction derives conclusions from fixed axioms; reflective equilibrium treats axioms as revisable inputs
diff.moral-ethical: moral reasoning applies normative content; reflective equilibrium is the method for refining that content iteratively
diff.dialectical: dialectic synthesizes thesis+antithesis into new thesis; reflective equilibrium iterates case-by-case, not argument-by-argument
diff.belief-revision: belief revision updates beliefs given new evidence; reflective equilibrium revises principles given judgments AND judgments given principles (bidirectional)
diff.calibration-epistemic-humility: calibration adjusts confidence in claims; reflective equilibrium adjusts the claims themselves, not just confidence
diff.meta-reasoning: meta-reasoning selects which mode to use; reflective equilibrium is one such mode, not the selector

common_confusions.why_confused: both involve self-correction and iterative refinement
common_confusions.distinction: calibration adjusts credences/confidence; reflective equilibrium adjusts the content of principles and judgments, not just certainty levels

common_confusions.why_confused: both update beliefs when conflicts arise
common_confusions.distinction: belief revision is unidirectional (evidence -> belief); reflective equilibrium is bidirectional (principles <-> judgments)
dialectic works on abstract arguments (thesis vs antithesis); reflective equilibrium works on principles vs concrete cases

signals: case_inventory shrinks between iterations without 'excluded because' entries
only 'easy' cases remain; all marked-hard cases were dropped or reclassified
revision_trace shows only judgment changes, never principle changes (one-way deference)
equilibrium reached in < 3 iterations on a novel domain
no adversarial cases in stress-test step; only author-generated cases tested
mitigations: HARD-CASE LOCK: flag 3+ cases as 'must-address' at step 1; equilibrium invalid if any are absent from final inventory
BIDIRECTION GATE: require >= 1 principle revision AND >= 1 judgment revision before certifying equilibrium
EXTERNAL STRESS: solicit 3 adversarial cases from a critic or red-team before step 8; document each and resolution
ITERATION FLOOR: for novel domains, require >= 4 full passes through steps 2-5 before stress-test
EXCLUSION AUDIT: any case removed requires a written justification citing which principle made it out-of-scope and why that scoping is principled
RESIDUAL DISCLOSURE: final certificate must list 1-3 residual tensions with explicit 'accepted because...' rationale

use: policy design: balancing general rules with edge cases while documenting exceptions
governance frameworks: building stakeholder buy-in by showing both sides adjusted
ethics development: refining moral principles through test cases, not just intuition-pumps
standard setting: harmonizing competing requirements with traceable trade-offs
value-laden decisions: producing principled justifications that survive adversarial scrutiny

steps: SEED: principles = [P1: minimize data collection, P2: enable fraud detection, P3: respect user consent]. Cases = [C1: marketing analytics, C2: security logging, C3: behavioral fraud signals, C4: third-party sharing for ads]
MAP: C1 conflicts P1 (analytics wants more data). C3 conflicts P1 (fraud needs behavioral data). C4 conflicts P3 (users didn't consent to ad partners)
WEIGH: P1 vs C3 intuition: fraud detection is a legitimate service purpose, intuition strong. P1 vs C1: marketing is nice-to-have, intuition weak
REVISE: narrow P1 to 'minimize data not required for stated service purpose'; C3 now passes. C1 still fails (marketing not stated purpose). Log revision
PROPAGATE: re-test C2 (security logging): passes under revised P1. Re-test C4: still fails P3 regardless of P1 change
ITERATE: second pass finds no new conflicts for C1-C4. Add adversarial C5: 'retain data for legal hold'; P1 tension. Revise P1 to 'minimize... except for legal/regulatory holds'. Third pass stable
STRESS-TEST: red-team proposes C6: 'sell anonymized data'. P1 silent, P3 arguable (consent unclear). Accept as residual tension
CERTIFY: equilibrium on 6 cases, 3 principles (each revised once), 1 residual tension (C6) documented with 'requires explicit consent language in future revision'

micro_example.context: deciding whether exceptions to a 'no meeting Fridays' policy should exist
micro_example.case: Critical incident requires cross-team sync on Friday
micro_example.tension: Principle forbids; intuition says incident response trumps productivity norm
micro_example.resolution: Principle revised to 'No routine meetings on Fridays; exceptions for P1 incidents with VP approval'
micro_example.test: Checked 5 prior Fridays; 3 would have passed (incidents), 2 would have failed (could wait). Equilibrium stable
